title: east-lothian-council-extension-big
story: The proposed extension to a cottage atGarleton, near Haddington, was rejected because East Lothian planners ruled it was bigger than the original building.However, their claim it was the same as building another house in the countryside, which goes against council policy, has been thrown out by councillors on appeal.A virtual meeting of the councilrsquos Local Review Body saw an appeal by the homeowners upheld after members said they were ldquocomfortable with the extension.The original plans to extend Nouster Cottage were, agents for the owners said, to allow an inter-generational family to live together at the property.The single-storey cottage, which had already had extensions added over the years, would have a new one and a half-storey extension including a boot room, hallway, playroom, snooker room and three bedrooms, and would add eight new rooms and two bathrooms to the three-bedroom cottage.But while planners described the extension as bigger than the house, agents APT Planning said that once outbuildings and a conservatory due to be demolished as part of the work were taken into account, it only made up a third of the cottagersquos footprint.They told the review body: ldquoWe strongly refute the conclusion that this is effectively a new house in the countryside, it very clearly is not.No objections to the plans were lodged but there were letters of support for the family.The agents said that the family bought the cottageto accommodate their growing multi-generational family.They added: ldquoThe family has two young boys and also an ageing parent with a degenerative disease.ldquoTheaccommodation has been designed with the three generations of family in mind, blending the needs of young and old and so that the grandparent can live comfortably on the ground floor .The review body agreed to uphold the appeal against the decision to refuse permission for the extension.Councillor John Williamson said: ldquoIt is an existingproperty being extended and I am comfortable approving it.Fellow review body member Jeremy Findlay agreed, along with convenorCouncillor John McMillan.A condition to replace or retain some trees which might be affected by the build was included and councillors also asked that a garage planned as part of the extension should have a condition stopping it from being used as additional accommodation.Councillor Findlay added: ldquoWe have had incidents in Gullane where people have built garages then surreptitiously added a room or two, so I feel strongly about this condition.

title: east-lothian-food-drink-businesses-vote-whether-continue-business-improvement-district
story: First created in , East Lothian Food  Drink Business Improvement District, in partnership with East Lothian Council and Queen Margaret University, has worked to promote East Lothian food and drink businesses.By creating a unying voice and marketing East Lothian as a quality provider of outstanding produce, the sector has benefited from a range of initiatives from direct selling to attendance at events and the creation of a digital marketing .Now, eligible businesses have the opportunity to vote on a second term and to continue to work together and drive the rebuilding of the food and drink sector in East Lothian following the impacts of recent lockdowns, stay-at-home orders and physical distancing.BIDs in Scotland have traditionally been focused on urban high streets, encompassing a number of dferent businesses. The East Lothian Food  Drink BID pioneered a new type of BID involving a single sector with a wider geographical area it remains the only food and drink sector BID in Scotland.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Provost, said: ldquoThe initial five years has seen many highlights and Scotlandrsquos Food  Drink County is fast becoming a highly visible brand.ldquoFrom member feedback, we know that working in this collaborative way is bringing real benefits.ldquoI would urge all eligible local businesses to vote to continue this fantastic collaboration for another five years.East Lothian Council has committed to continued financial support of the BIDthe vote to continue for a further five years is successful.It will also continue to provide expertise through membership of the board and the support of the economic development team.Chris Luca, chair of East Lothian Food  Drink, said: ldquoAs a local food and drink producer, the East Lothian Food  Drink BID has provided us with a great opportunity to work together and make the changes we as a sector want.

but they need a bit longer to do that."We also need a bit more time to be confident than we are now that vaccination will stop the rising case numbers today becoming severe illness and sharply rising hospital numbers a couple of weeks from now."So for all these reasons, I can confirm today that regrettably, Glasgow will remain in Level  for another week at this stage."I know, not least because I live in Glasgow myself, how unwelcome this is for iniduals and businesses - but I hope it wont be for much longer."Nicola Sturgeon announced that East Renfrewshire will stay in Level  despite high case numbers.The First Minister said: "On the face of it, levels in East Renfrewshire - as a proportion of the population - are actually slightly higher than in Glasgow."Im acutely aware that people might therefore look at the raw data and sayGlasgow is in Level , East Renfrewshire should be there too."But as youve heard me say many times before, and I know this is really dficult, the situation underneath the raw data is often more complex and its the detailed analysis that we must try to base our decisions on."For example, while the cases per , in Glasgow and East Renfrewshire are similar, the total number of cases in East Renfrewshire - because its a smaller area, obviously - is signicantly smaller than in Glasgow."To illustrate that, yesterday there were actually just  new cases reported in East Renfrewshire - compared to  in Glasgow. More importantly, many more of the cases in East Renfrewshire can be traced to specic household clusters, unlike in Glasgow."That means that we think strong and targeted public health measures have more of a chance of stemming the rise in East Renfrewshire, without the need to use wider restrictions."Taking all of that into account, our judgement - and these decisions are often finely balanced - is that East Renfrewshire should stay at Level  for now, although this will be kept under close review and well continue to use enhanced public health measures."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will move to Level  from midnight tonight.Ms Sturgeon said: "Im very pleased to say that the situation has actually improved very signicantly."Last week, the area was reporting  new cases a week per , - and its been made possible by efforts of local public health teams and the public."I would say though that its important to remain careful."Being in Level  still comes with necessary restrictions, so please stick to those and do everything you can to help Moray to enjoy more freedoms and more easing of restrictions later this summer."The First Minister announced travel restrictions between Scotland and three areas in England.NS: "However, there are particularly serious outbreaks of the April- iant in three specic areas of England: Bedford, Bolton and Blackburn  Darwen."For that reason, from Monday, we are imposing temporary travel restrictions on travel between Scotland and those  areas."Soyou were planning to visit friends or relatives, or to say in those areas - story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. title: we-lost-dad-cant-mum-yet-p-k-thinks-can-drive-269-miles-babysitter-glasgow-reacts-dominic-cummings

title: pro-union-parties-indyref2-obsession-fuelling-debate
story: In part, this obsession has led to the SNP being let off the hook for its failures in government as was reflected in this weekendrsquos election results and perpetuated by every media outlet across the country zoning in on constitutional questions.Over the past few weeks, the majority of pro-Union politicians have used every sound clip offered to them to exclaim their anti-independence thoughts rather than explain how they propose to get this country back on its feet and how they could work with the Government to put recovery first.With all eyes focused on the constitution, it has worked in the favour of the SNP who have managed to be elected to Government with a record number of votes, despite their failings over the past  years in charge.The First Minister herself admitted during the campaign that she had taken her ldquoeye off the ball as Scotland racked up the highest drugs death in Europe. But there doesnrsquot appear to have been any rebuke for the drugs deaths crisis, their failed education record, missed hospital waiting time targets, rising child poverty rates, the exam results scandal, or failures in local policing.The next Scottish Government has an opportunity over the next five years to make amends for past failures and getting caught up in an independence campaign will only take the SNPrsquos eye off the ball once again.However, the SNP did not win a majority in the election and as a minority government will require support from other parties to pass budgets and any major reforms.The Scottish Greens will likely prop up the SNP in future policy discussions, but this will requirepolicy trade-offs infor budget support.With COP firmly in the sights of both parties as an opportunity to showcase Scotland as a leader in tackling climate change on the global stage, will the Scottish Greens be willing to lend support to independence which could risk the SNP taking its focus off meeting its emissions reduction targets of % by  ndash which it has done for the past two years in a row.They have already said they want bold action from the Scottish Government and now they are in a position to bargain for this.Read more:Indyref and a blinkered green agenda could harm Scottish farmings futureDuring Sundayrsquos Andrew Marr programme, a suggestion of next spring to hold another referendum was put to the First Minister, to which, of course, she said she was contemplating. Nicola Sturgeon hasnrsquot officially committed to a timescale, other than the first half of the next parliamentary term, but it would appear that the media is setting the ball rolling by proposing such a timeline. As much as I have criticised the SNP for pedalling talks of Indyref during a pandemic, journalists are also guilty of fuelling the debate and diminishing print space or airtime for more immediate and pressing issues.Over the past week I have been moving into my new house, which has involved many hours of deep cleaning whilst tuned in to my radio and coverage of the election.Hats off to BBC Radio Scotland team for managing to fill three daysrsquo worth of election coverage with very little to report on other than the one major news story: would the SNP gain a majority Although they covered results and reaction across the entire country, the main topic on every reportersrsquo lips was whether the SNP would have a mandate to hold another referendum. So, for every listener tuned in, we are being told that this is the discussion we need to be having, this is the headline we should all be taking away.In between googling tutorials on how to sand kitchen worktops, I checked in to the community Facebook page for my local village and was struck by the fact that none of the members were remotely engaged in discussions over the election, let alone independence. Like many other communities across the country, this village is still in the grips of a pandemic, so quite understandably, most posts and discussions revolved around Covid advice and best practice, information about the local youth club reopening, as well as a series of church services.Read more:Scottish election: Indyref cant continue to dominate the next five years mdash there are bigger issuesMembers were posting aboutfitness camps and slots which had come available for hairdressers and beauty salons. Local businesses desperate to rebuild and get customers in their doors.Economic recovery is what matters to so many, yet we are so embroiled in constitutional questions that we lose sight of the ramications the past year has had for so many businesses and iniduals who have lost their jobs and families living below thepoverty line.There is no denying the fact that there is indeed an appetite to reopen the debate around independence, the recent vote shows an almost   split down the middle, but I do not believe it should be up to the media to frame the discussion.There is a huge job ahead for the next Scottish Government to deliver on a national recovery and all opposition politicians and members of the press must be focused on holding them accountable for the measures they are taking to get the country back on its feet.Letrsquos not do Alex Salmondrsquos job for him by inadvertently holding the SNPrsquos feet to the fire over independence but instead hold their feet to the fire over the nationrsquos recovery from the pandemic.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: scots-word-week-grimlins
story: I HOPE folk attending the coming Orkney Folk Festival will have a good time, despite its virtual nature this year.Whilst many Scots on the mainland would describe our y summer twilight as the ldquogloaming, in Orkney it is described as the ldquogrimlins. The Dictionaries of the Scots Languagedefines it as ldquotwilight, the first or last gleams of daylight. The word is derived from Norwegian ldquogrimla, to ldquoglimmer, twinkle, blink.In , the DSL records this from the Old-Lore Miscellany of Orkney: ldquoBit alis, alis, whin da grimlins camrsquo anrsquo he gaed tae geong hame feinty sheep nor shoon fand he. Later, in , John Firth writes in Reminiscences of an Orkney Parish : ldquoIn the lsquogrimmelingsrsquo the youngsters were employed to strip the green peel off [the rushes] leaving the white pith, lsquoas saft as silkrsquo which, swimming in sillock [coalfish] oil, barely made darkness visible.Still with the DSL, but more recently, the Orcadian of December  records: ldquoI was walking home along the shore in the grimlins when, from the Burn of Gairsty, I saw a flash of light at the end of our house where my father was lighting his pipe.Research, of course, can show us even more recent evidence, as in the following example from Alastair Macleodrsquos historical novel Bright Shining Woman : ldquoIn the grimlins the cold air made for a sound sleep although this was summer temperatures dropped to just about four degrees Celsius and blankets or furs were still needed.Scots Word of the Week is written by Pauline Cairns Speitel, Dictionaries of the Scots Language, https:dsl.ac.uk.

title: cat-deeley-swapping-hollywood-home
story: Deeley, , who found fame co-presenting Saturday morning childrenrsquos show SM:TV Live with Ant and Dec in the late s and has spent the past  years hosting the popular US reality competition So You Think You Can Dance, isnrsquot one for trite soundbites.There are no guarded pauses. Or checking with her publicist that she is saying the right thing. Deeley is funny and self-deprecating, peppering our conversation with amusing anecdotes and the impression she doesnrsquot take herself too seriously.As the TV presenterrsquos voice drts down the line on a weekday morning in May, she chats breezily about swapping Los Angeles for London, on-air disasters, romantic gestures, pandemic le and how she recently had a spring lamb named in her honour.Deeley is in good form. ldquoI love to feel comfortable in my own skin, she says. ldquoSome days I can rock a black leather mini dress and other days I want something floral, whimsical and vintage, then some days I want an androgynous trouser suit.The reason we are talking clothes is that Deeley has newly launched a collaboration with luxury knitwear brand, Winser London, to create a womenswear capsule collection.Therersquos a Scottish link with the Geelong lambswool yarn produced at the Todd  Duncan mill on the banks of Loch Leven in Kinross and the garments then handcrafted at Teviot Knitwear Hawick, an artisan manufacturer in the Borders.Presenter Cat Deeley models her Knit by Cat Deeley for Winser London collection. Picture: Joseph Sinclair Winser LondonHer debut range, Knit by Cat Deeley for Winser London, comprises three pieces: a hooded cardigan, poncho and zip-neck jumper. She cites a  photograph of Marilyn Monroe on Santa Monica Beach as one of her main inspirations.ldquoIt is an iconic picture, says Deeley. ldquoShe is on the beach, a bit windswept and full of le. She has got on this cardigan that you just know she has had for years ndash JFK may have even given it to her. It feels like an heirloom.ldquoShe has thrown the cardigan on over the top of her swimsuit. She has obviously spent the day on the beach. Her bones feel warm, you can smell the sunshine on her skin.ldquoThe other real person I drew from is Jeff Bridges in The Big Lebowski. I love his Dude cardigan. If you throw on a piece of knitwear that is that comfy and cool with great colourways, it is a real heirloom piece you are going to keep forever.Starting her own label has been a long-held dream. ldquoI love clothes ndash I always have done, ever since I was a little girl, says Deeley, adding that she doesnrsquot have a stylist for her day-to-day wardrobe or TV appearances.Fancy frocks ndash as she swtly claries ndash are a trickier beast. ldquoIf you are talking ballgowns that you would go to the Emmys in, then I need at least three stylists because you canrsquot get even those bad boys on and off by yourself, she jokes.:The art of a sex scene: Vanessa Coffey on how she creates on-screen intimacyldquoThere is no way of doing that on your own and God forbid you need to pee or anything like that ndash it is a disaster. So, for things like that, I do need a stylist, but for other things I donrsquot.While living and working in the US, Deeley hosted  seasons of Foxrsquos hit show So You Think You Can Dance, garnering five Emmy nominations and earning an estimated pound million fortune.She ed to the UK in early  with her comedian husband Patrick Kielty and their sons Milo, five, and James, two.The decision to move home was largely prompted by a desire to spend more time with family and the fact that Milo was approaching school age.Their plan was to get Milo settled into his new school and then spend their summer holidays back in LA where Deeley would film the next series of So You Think You Can Dance.ldquoWe moved heaven and earth, she recalls. ldquoI flew here with the dog. I left her with my brother. I found a flat with a big garden because they needed to have space. I flew back [to LA] and we packed up the house."Then we brought the kids here. Milo started school and he loved it. We were high-fiving and saying, lsquoWe have got this, we have managed to do itrsquo. Then the global pandemic hit. Just when you think you have everything completely sorted, the whole thing goes topsy turvy.Presenter Cat Deeley models her Knit by Cat Deeley for Winser London collection. Picture: Joseph Sinclair Winser LondonDeeley was filming when the first lockdown loomed last year. ldquoIn the March, I flew back to LA to do a show for Disney and then everything started shutting down. I flew back [to the UK] because I was frightened that they were going to shut all the borders.While perhaps not the homecoming she had envisaged, Deeley is sanguine. ldquoWe love being back here because of friends and family, she says. ldquoYou have such a small window when the kids want to hang out with the grandparents and everybody wants to hang out together."I will never get those moments backwe donrsquot do something about it now. There are certain things I miss. I love being on the beach, the palm trees and sunshine ndash all of that kind of stuff.Their new base, so far, is shaping up nicely. ldquoBritain takes some serious beating in the summertime when the sun is shining and the blossom is all out, she enthuses. ldquoBecause you donrsquot really have seasons so much in LA.:Polkemmet Country Park: Woodland walks, a rich history and that curious Teletubbies hornldquoIt was right place, right time, she says. ldquoBecause of everything that happened, it means that you canrsquot travel as much as I used to.ldquoEverything has changed in everybodyrsquos world right now. I have actually had more time than I would normally doing my normal day job to get really involved with it. I find it exciting. It is lovely to try new things and have a go at creating something.ldquoI will ask: lsquoWhatrsquos this ribbing called rsquo or lsquoCould we make that a bit bigger rsquo. I donrsquot know the right terms or phrases ndash the Winser team have had so much patience. Irsquom sure that the questions to them are absolutely inane, but my enthusiasm makes up for my lack of technical knowledge.Her stint hosting Lorraine coincided with a segment from Countryfile presenter Adam Hensonrsquos farm in the Cotswolds. ldquoThere were two lambs born live on air and Adam said, lsquoThis one is Cat and this one is Lorraine helliprsquo she recalls.ldquoMy boys love animals. They adore nature documentaries, they love David Attenborough, they are so into their animals. I said to Adam, lsquoWould it be OK to bring the boys rsquo and I am sure he thought I was just making conversation on TV.ldquoI got home and as I walked through the door, Milo was like, lsquoMum! When are we going to the farm rsquo I managed to stalk Adam ndash letrsquos call it what it is ndash on Instagram and askedI could bring the boys and he said, lsquoYeah, great.rsquoPresenter Cat Deeley models her Knit by Cat Deeley for Winser London collection. Picture: Joseph Sinclair Winser LondonWhen Deeley realised it might be a bit far for a day trip, she swtly improvised a good-old fashioned family adventure. ldquoWe ended up staying in a safari tent, she says. ldquoI thought: lsquoIn for a penny, in for a poundrsquo. So, I actually met Cat and Lorraine.Deeley has long been Britainrsquos favourite girl next door. Growing up in suburban Sutton Coldfield near Birmingham, she had aspired to be a Blue Peter presenter. At , Deeley was scouted as a model at The Clothes Show.She moved on to co-host the MTV chart show, Hitlist UK, with Edith Bowman, then joined SM:TV Live and its spin-off CD:UK in .The showbiz industry has changed markedly since Deeley started out, not least with the advent of social media. Is she glad to have begun her career in simpler times, pre-Twitter, Facebook and TikTok et al ldquoOh, my goodness, yeah, she says. ldquoBecause I think it is so easy to be unkindly brave when you are nameless and faceless and hidden behind a keyboard.ldquoI think everybodyrsquos opinion, of course, matters. Everybody should have an opinion. That is absolutely of the utmost importance.:Scotlands Home of the Year: Anna Campbell-Jones on why it is must-watch tellyldquoHowever, how you choose to deal with those peoplersquos opinions depends on you. I am close to my family. I have an amazing collection of friends that I could probably count on two hands. They are honest with me when I need them to be. I know that any opinion they have comes from a place of love for me.ldquoMy mum and my dad, they never pussyfoot around me. If there is something that needs to be said orI need a telling off, they absolutely do it. Those are the opinions I hold in highest regard.Deeley believes she is equipped to deal with the darker side of social media in a way that might not have been possibleshe was only now starting out as a fledgling presenter.ldquoI feel like I am  years old, big and ugly enough, and have been in this business for a long time. It is easy for me to not put too much importance on it."Whereas I feel thatIrsquod had that around me when I was starting out and , that would be quite tough to deal with. It would have been dficult to compartmentalise and separate off lsquothis is me doing a job on screenrsquo and lsquothis is me as just a girl, personallyrsquo.ldquoAnt and Dec and I talk about it all the time. The fact that we didnrsquot have social media probably meant that we stayed on and people saw the SM:TV that we finally got to when we were having fun, comfortable with ourselves and had found that chemistry.Cat Deeley with Ant  Dec who she co-presented Saturday morning childrenrsquos show SM:TV Live with in the s. Picture: GettyldquoThat would never have happened today because it would have affected us too much. I also think it would have affected the broadcasters. The other luxury we had was that they didnrsquot give up on us.She chuckles reminiscing about those early days. ldquoNigel [Pickard, who commissioned SM:TV] has said that was because they didnrsquot have anything  to put in the slot. And no one was watching anyway. But it meant we got time to practise and to find that chemistry.ldquoIt doesnrsquot matter whether it is on screen or a TV show or presenters or friends ndash you canrsquot hothouse that chemistry. You canrsquot hothouse friendship. The best friendships come about purely from time passing and things happening to you.ldquoThe best moments. The worst moments. Moments of heartbreak. Moments of celebration. That is what makes friendships, the chemistry on a TV show or the relationship between you and an audience, work. You feel you have grown up together and become friends slowly over a period of time.Speaking of chemistry, Deeley first met and became good friends with her husband Patrick Kielty, , while they were co-presenting the BBC talent show Fame Academy in .That friendship blossomed into something deeper a few years later when Kielty decided to surprise Deeley by hopping on a last-minute flight from Belfast to Los Angeles for her birthday brunch at the Beverly Hills Hotel. The couple married in .Cat Deeley and her husband Patrick Kielty co-hosted BBC talent show Fame Academy. Picture: BBCIs he still a big romantic  She laughs heartily. ldquoErr, I think that was definitely the pinnacle. But in all honesty, you would have to be in a Richard Curtis film to beat that, wouldnrsquot you ldquoNow it is normally quite dficult to get somebody to text you back or to swipe right. It was definitely the romance of it, but it was also how noble and brave the gesture was too. It took some serious chutzpah.Deeley says she feels she has earned her stripes. At what point did that become the case  ldquoWhen disasters happen, she says. ldquoI have said the wrong thing. I have forgotten my lines. I havenrsquot got a show off on time. I have fallen over. I have tripped up.ldquoI had one dancer jump over my head in a split kick, I then fell over but managed to hold on to the mic on a live TV show in four-inch heels."I got my first migraine on TV. I have done live TV and had food poisoning at the same time. I have been doing it for a long time so everything that could possibly happen has, at some stage, happened to me, probably live on air ndash not even pre-recorded.Deeley giggles at the memories of her mishaps. ldquoWhen I got the dancer to jump over me on So You Think You Can Dance, I came home and Paddy said to me: lsquoWhat on earth were you thinking rsquo I was like: lsquoOh my God, wasnrsquot it brilliant rsquo He said: lsquoYou could have actually broken your neck on live TV, you absolute buffoon.rsquoldquoThat is what I mean by earning my stripes. When things go wrong or mistakes happen,you can laugh about it, andyou can make it comfortable for the audience, then normally it makes them like you more.Presenter Cat Deeley models her Knit by Cat Deeley for Winser London collection. Picture: Joseph Sinclair Winser LondonDeeley enjoys a good blooper reel. ldquoYou know when Joanna Lumley and Jenner Saunders messed up on Absolutely Fabulous and you watch the outtakes  I love that, she says.ldquoMistakes happen to everybody in le. Because unless you are brave enough to have a go at something hellip Of course, there are going to be mistakes, there are going to be trips and falls, but you learn from them.:Chapel of the heart: How Orkneys wartime past inspired a new novel"If you can pick yourself up, get on with it, make a bit of a joke and laugh at yourself, I think that is when entertainment is at its very best.Knit by Cat Deeley for Winser London, is available exclusively on winserlondon

title: falkland-palace-travel-outlander-history-real-tennis
story: The inspiration was the great French chateaux of the time such as the sumptuous royal palace at Fontainebleau near Paris, and the main driver of the project was James IV. From  until his death in  he set about transforming the place, bringing in orange trees for the gardens and skilled stonemasons to work on the building, stocking the surrounding park land with deer and wild boar, and importing cultural treats such as lute players from Italy and an un-named African drummer.James V extended the buildings and it was him we have to thanks for one of its most famous additions: the real tennis court. Its known as the Sport of Kings and for good reason: Henry VIII was a noted adherent, and there were courts at Hampton Court by . The ones at Falkland Palace were completed by  and are still used today by the Falkland Palace Royal Tennis Club.Mary Queen of Scots was another royal who was fond of the palace, though its history isnrsquot all bucolic splendour and architectural finery: as part of his machinations against James VI, the duplicitous Earl of Bothwell tried to capture the king at Falkland on the morning of June , . He and his men were eventually repulsed and several of them were eventually hanged in Edinburgh.Both Charles I and Charles II visited Falkland Place but after the Union of the Crowns the palace gradually fell into disrepair ndash until the late th century, that is, when the Marquess of Bute embarked on a  year restoration project. This resulted in the building of a glass house and the planting of an avenue of lime trees. In the s, celebrated designer Percy Cane redesigned the gardens and theyrsquore now almost as big a draw as the palace itself. The gardens are currently , and the building itself will re-open on May .What to watchUnsurprisingly, Falkland Palace is one of the many Scottish historical sites used on the television series Outlander. It features in the penultimate episode of the second series.

title: bob-dylan-amy-adam-netflix-gary-oldman-blade-runner
story: Star Trek Beyond, Film , pmCaptain James T Kirkis considering relinquishing the bridge because "things have started to feel a little... episodic". He keeps his plans secret from the rest of the crew including human-Vulcan science officer Spock . During a visit to a Federation starbase under the control of Commodore Paris , Kirk and the team respond to a distress call issued by an alien called Kalara . The Enterprise subsequently comes under attack from otherworldly despot Kralland his swarming drones. Star Trek Beyond is a familiar conflation of past, future and present that fails to set its phasers to stun, although scriptwriters Simon Pegg and Doug Jung stoke the comedic ante with a slew of wry one-liners.TuesdaySnatched, Film , pmSelf-absorbed dreamer Emily Middletonis unceremoniously dumped by her boyfriend Michaelshortly before a non-refundable trip to Ecuador. Unable to persuade one of her female friends to accompany her on the South American odyssey, Emily turns instead to her sensible mother Linda . While the matriarch befriends fellow holidaymakers Barband Ruth , thrill-seeker Emily sparks a boozy romance with handsome stranger James . One night of passion leads to disaster and notorious crime lord Morgadoholds Emily and her mother hostage for ,. Its great to see Hawn back after a -year break from the movies, but its a shame the script couldnt find more funny lines for her.WednesdayThe Darkest Minds, Film , pmSixteen-year-old Ruby Dalyis a survivor of a pathogen with the unwieldy name Idiopathic Adolescent Acute Neurodegeneration , which has delivered a fatal blow to % of the worldrsquos children. Youngsters who are resistant to IAAN are colour-coded: Green, Blue and Yellow are permitted to live under armed guard, while Orange and Red are eliminated via lethal injection. Ruby is an Orange but she lives under the radar as a Green in Thurmond rehabilitation camp. Kindly medic Dr Cate Connorrisks her le to smuggle Ruby out of the facility to join the fight against US President Grayas part of the Childrenrsquos League. The Darkest Minds conjures dystopian nightmares that will be achingly familiar to fans of the Hunger Games and Divergent series, but itrsquos anchored by the luminous Stenberg.ThursdayBlade Runner , Sony Movies, pmDirector Denis Villeneuves sequel honours the past and expands the nihilistic universe imagined by Philip K Dick in his novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep  Ryan Gosling stars as an android -hunter working for the LAPD who uncovers a secret and goes in search of the detectivewho could provide him with answers. Mots from Ridley Scotts  film reverberate tantalisingly throughout, deftly stitching together two timelines without completely excluding audiences who are ignorant of the original. However, for all its bravura production design and flawless special effects, the film doesnt smack gobs with its invention. Like the automata that enrich human lives, Villeneuves film is one small yet signicant iteration shy of perfection.Film of the WeekFridayDonrsquot Look Back, BBC Four, pmBob Dylan turns  on May  and amid a raft of programming dedicated to the le and work of the iconic musician BBC Four is showing DA Pennebakerrsquos  documentary, shot during Dylanrsquos short but eventful  tour of England. The filmrsquos best known segment is the one which opens it ndash Dylan standing on a street corner as Subterranean Homesick Blues plays, throwing away large cue cards on which the lyrics are written while Beat poet Allan Ginsberg stands behind him ndash but virtually every other scene is an unalloyed treat. Kurt Cobain wasnrsquot entirely right when he said Donrsquot Look Back is the only good rock documentary, but itrsquos probably in the top three best ones. The tour itself only lasted about  days, but Donrsquot Look Back is still being pored over half a century later.Dylan, of course, is its beating heart. So young, confident and charismatic. So cool in his sunglasses and leather jacket. Itrsquos no surprise that Pennebakerrsquos camera follows him endlessly, whether hersquos sparring with journalists, trying to explain himself to pompous backstage interlopers ndash serious young men in jackets and ties, mostly ndash or ignoring everything and bashing away at his typewriter. Pennebakerrsquos unobtrusive, fly-on-the-wall style means you really do see him as his closest friends and confidantes would have, while the generous amount of concert footage gives a flavour of the audience experience as well.If the film has a co-star itrsquos Joan Baez, who accompanied Dylan on the tour. Alternating between warm, goofy and beatic, her after-hours, hotel room performances of Percyrsquos Song and Love Is A Four Letter Wordare stand-outs. Tour manager Bob Neuwirth, never seen without his sunglasses, is another ever-present, as is Dylanrsquos manager, folk impresario Albert Grossman.Marianne Faithfull and Cream drummer Ginger Baker are supposedly visible in background shots somewhere but good luck spotting them . However you canrsquot miss Donovan or Alan Price, who had just left The Animals. The former performs for Dylan in his hotel room but his thunder is well and truly stolen when Dylan follows To Sing For You with Itrsquos All Over Now, Baby Blue. You canrsquot out-Dylan Bob Dylan, is the moral of that scene. Whether you love Dylan or not, this is a genuine classic.And one to stream hellipThe Woman In The Window, NetflixBlending Alfred Hitchcockrsquos Rear Window with elements of s thriller Copycat and ndash spoiler alert ndash Abi Morganrsquos  BBC drama River, Joe Wrightrsquos thriller stars Amy Adamsas Dr Anna Fox, a child psychologist and extreme agoraphobic whose curtain-twitching interest in the goings on in her wealthy New York neighbourhood takes a weird and unhealthy turn when a new family moves in. They are the Russells ndash mother Jane , rich banker father Alistairand -year-old son Ethan , whorsquos the first of them to introduce himself. He comes bearing a gt ndash a lavender candle ndash followed shortly by Jane, who stays for drinks and dashes off a sketch of Anna as they talk. Alistair, when she meets him, is brusque and aggressive.Apart from those visitors, the only other people Anna sees are her lodger David , and her psychiatrist Dr Landy . Shersquos amicably separated from her husband Ed , though they talk regularly on the phone. He lives where with their young daughter, Olivia . Itrsquos to Ed that Anna first recounts the arrival of the Russells, what she has heard about them and, of course, how much they paid for their swanky townhouse.Everything changes, however, when Anna thinks she witnesses a murder there. But did she see what she thought she saw, or is her excessive drinking combining adversely with her new prescription drugs to make her to imagine things that arenrsquot there  Did Jane Russell ever actually visit her, andshe did can she prove it  And what is it that has caused her agoraphobia Oldman and Moore are a little under-used but itrsquos great to see Jenner Jason Leigh on screen and reprising some of her Single White Female creepiness. Still, the large, gloomy townhouse makes the perfect backdrop for Wrightrsquos tight psycho-drama and therersquos enough in the way of twists and set-piece reveals to keep you guessing until the end.

story: Changing roomsAS for Mr Blackfordrsquos other home, it seems thatrsquos a tad too rustic. He has just applied to have it extended by adding a ldquoutility room close to the kitchen and a larger bedroom upstairs with useable headroom and wardrobe storage space. Just like it was before the Clearances, no doubt. However last year he also applied to add a more authentic country item. David Cameron got himself a Shepherds Hut. Mr Blackford went for a corrugated metal Nissen Hut. A capacious m by m, it must be invaluable for storing all his money.The Commons TouchTALKING of humility, new SNP Constitution Secretary Angus Robertson appears to offer seamless continuity from his predecessor, Michael Russell, who was famously described as wanting to die in his own arms. A mole tells us Angus was equally modest in an induction session for new MSPs, banging on about his old job as an MP and referring to Westminster as ldquothe other place. Ken Macintosh, the outgoing Presiding Officer, told the session to remember all MSPs were equal in the chamber and all would get their turn to speak. ldquoExcept Angus, whorsquos said enough already.Salty rides again JUBILATION in the SNP after Anum Qaisar-Javed won the Westminster byelection in Airdrie  Shotts. But is everything so rosy locally  Unspun hears former MSP Richard Lyle - known as Salty Dick for once claiming a poke of chips on his Holyrood expenses - is eyeing ato his old council fiefdom in next yearrsquos local elections. We hear Salty even fancies being council leader, something which might disappoint the current leader of the SNP opposition there, his former lackey Jordan Linden. An over-the-hill politician trying to make a comeback at the expense of their protege  It must be an SNP thing.Keep it in the familyALSO causing trouble and stre, we hear, are the staff arrangements for the former MP for Airdire  Shotts, the SNPrsquos Neil Gray, who is now the local MSP. While at Westminster, Mr Gray employed his brother-in-law as his office manager. But Holyroodrsquos rules were tightened about five years ago, and so Mr Gray is forbidden from putting his relation on the public payroll. We hear there is much scrabbling around to find the beloved bro-in-law a cosy number with another MSP instead.Whip lashedA shaky start for new Tory chief whip Stephen Kerr after he tried to move his MSPs to better seats in the chamber. He was chased off by an old hand from another party. ldquoI didnrsquot exactly tell him he was a p****, the winner relates. ldquoI said, Stephen, wersquore going to be working together for five years, donrsquot be a p****. Now thatrsquos diplomacy!

title: meet-rebecca-strong---glasgow-matron-made-modern-nursing
story: If anything, it was a casual occupation which attracted impoverished and unskilled women - often prostitutes - who saw it as an easy way to earn some ldquogin money.Some did not even wait until their work was over, getting disgracefully drunk on the hospital wards during night shts.ldquoThis was pre-s, said Dr Kate Stevens, a consultant nephrologist in Glasgow.ldquoWhen nursing started out it tended to be people who were lsquoalso ransrsquo might be the best description. Often it was people who were in prostitution.ldquoNursing wasnrsquot a profession. They didnrsquot nurse the way they nurse now. They werenrsquot caring for sick people.ldquoThey were often drunk. Theyrsquod be bribed and given threepence to buy themselves some gin - and that would encourage them to give slightly better care.ldquoThese were people who turned up, stoked the fire, mopped the floors, gave the patients some food.ldquoThen there were the night nurses, which was the worst job ever. They would have to be hidden in cupboards sometimes because they were absolutely plastered on the job and theyrsquod be carried out in the morning.ldquoIt was really an excuse to sit around and have a few drinks.: Joseph Lister, X-rays and nursing - how Glasgow Royal Infirmary changed medicineThe transformation of nursing - in Scotland and around the world - can be credited in large part to Glasgow Royal Infirmarys pioneering first matron, Rebecca Strong.A widowed single mother who had trained under Florence Nightingale in London, Mrs Strong initially served as matron at Dundee Royal Infirmary from  before taking up the newly created post at Glasgows oldest hospital in , aged .Rebecca StrongIt was there that she formed a strong friendship with acclaimed surgeon William Macewen - renowned for performing the worlds first successful operation to remove a brain tumour at the GRI in .ldquoThere were a lot of theories about why they were such allies, but he was very keen to ensure that antisepsis techniques were applied," said Dr Stevens, co-founder of the charity Friends of GRI which is set to celebrate the achievements of Rebecca Strong and other groundbreaking GRI females during a series of Womens Week online events, starting on Monday.: William Macewen - the pioneering Glasgow surgeon behind the worlds breakthrough brain tumour opShe added: "[Macewen] believed that for him to do the best surgery he really needed to have the best nursing staff around him."It didnrsquot matter how clean he was -he was using gloves and carbolic acid -the nurses were dirty and drunk, the surgery wasnrsquot really going to be a success.Over the course of her career at the GRI - she retired in  - Mrs Strong fought to improve the conditions for nurses and single-handedly moulded it into a serious and accredited profession.William Macewen, who was highly supportive of Rebecca Strongs mission to train nurses professionallyldquoShe completely revolutionised nursing," said Dr Stevens."Florence Nightingale obviously started the whole thing off, but Rebecca Strong really transformed things up here.ldquoWhen she first arrived it was dirty. The nurses didnrsquot have proper breaks, there was no discipline, no regimented regime on the wards, they didnrsquot have a unorm."By the time she left in  there was a nursing school and people were getting certicates for their qualications.ldquoWhat she achieved was really nothing short of phenomenal. She described herself as a lsquotroublesome womanrsquo - but therersquos no way she could have achieved what she did without being a troublesome woman. She was like a dog with a bone.ldquoWhen managers said lsquonorsquo she went back and back and back: lsquoI need time for my staffrsquo lsquothey need to have proper restrsquo lsquothey need holidaysrsquo lsquowe want a nursesrsquo homersquo."In fact she left the Royal when they refused to build a nursesrsquo home - then came back once it was built. She was so incensed that they werenrsquot getting what she felt was necessary.ldquoHer methods in terms of nurse training are now used worldwide." attends a nurses league meeting at Glasgow Royal Infirmary in " alt"HeraldScotland: Rebecca Strongattends a nurses league meeting at Glasgow Royal Infirmary in " class"editor-image"Rebecca Strongattends a nurses league meeting at Glasgow Royal Infirmary in Among those delighted to see her remembered this week is David Geyer, her -year-old great-grandson who lives in Kilcreggan, near Helensburgh.Even now, he remembers her as a formidable character.Mr Geyer, who is originally from Yorkshire, said: "I remember her coming to see us in Wakefield, where we lived, in the summer of  - not long before the war broke out. I was ."We went to the railway station to meet her and you can imagine this station - mid-morning, not much of colour - and then out steps Rebecca Strong from the carriage, dressed up to the nines in the most beautul clothing."She strode towards us, fit as a fiddle aged . She was quite amazing."David Geyer observing a commemorative plaque at Glasgow Royal Infirmary in honour of its first matron, Rebecca StrongIn retirement she had become a globetrotting lecturer in nursing, often visiting North America.That visit to Wakefield, however, travelling from her then-home in Chester, was the last time Mr Geyer saw his great-grandmother. She died in , aged .He recalls being aware of her as "a famous nurse", but said it was not something she or the family really discussed."It wasnrsquot a subject brought up in conversation," said Mr Geyer, one of three surviving great-grandsons.ldquoWersquore all very pleased that shersquos being remembered. It would be a pityshe disappeared without somebody singing her praises.: Lindsey Fitzharris on le, death and surgery in the th CenturyWomens Week will also celebrate the contribution of the Dorcas Society, a charity founded at the GRI in  by Beatrice Cogston and journalist Annie Church to provide basic comforts and visits to patients isolating during the cholera epidemic.ldquoThey spoke to the wives of the doctors working at the Royal and basically said lsquohow can you sit in your posh living rooms when your husbandsrsquo patients are in dire need of basics ," said Dr Hilary Wilson, a consultant rheumatologist and co-founder of the Friends of GRI.ldquoWhen the patients came into hospital their clothes were often fumigated and burnt, and then they were left to go back out into the street with very little warm clothing so they would end up back at the Royal."These were people without relatives to visit them."Dr Kate Stevens and Dr Hilary Wilson, who set up the Friends of GRI charity to celebrate the -year-old hospitals history and heritageMs Cogston raised funds for the Dorcas Society through bazaars and fetes, including one at Kibble Palace in  which raised pound, to open a convalescent home - now demolished - in Broomhill."She was a revolutionary woman," said Dr Wilson. "She gave away all her possessions. She didnrsquot have any money left at the end of her le such that her friends had to buy her an annuity so that she had some income."The Dorcas tradition was continued by Mabel McKinley, who visited patients in hospital after the First World War and established the Mabels tearoom at GRI whose profits still go to the charity.ldquoThey provide equipment for the wards, they provide clothing, they supply articial limbs to patients," said Dr Wilson."Only yesterday one of my patients had to get a pair of joggers, a T-shirt and some shoes lsquofrom the Dorcas roomrsquo - so we still have that every day at the Royal."As for being a woman, in the modern-day world of medicine, Professor Jackie Taylor - the first ever female president of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons Glasgow - says "persistence and determination" remain important, but strongly advocates "nurturing" talent and having more females in leadership roles.Professor Jackie Taylor, president of the RCPSGProf Taylor, a consultant geriatrician who has trained and worked at the GRI herself, added that there was "silent expectation" as a junior doctor that she would move on into general practice.She said: "When I said lsquono I would like to stay in hospital medicinersquo there was surprise. That gives me hope though because that shows how much things have changed - it isnrsquot assumed that every female doctor will go into general practice."Things are changing, we are making progress. In my own career,I wanted to have a family - I have two grown up children now - the options to work flexibly really werenrsquot there and that was tough because it was a case of coming back and training full time, or taking a long career break - or potentially leaving.": More than half of female surgeons encounter sexism in the workplaceNonetheless, Prof Taylor notes that in some surgical specialties such as orthopaedics only % of consultants are female."We are actually seeing higher numbers of women go into training in surgical specialties but wersquore not keeping them and taking them all the way through to a consultant post"Sometimes the culture can be an issue.Wersquove worked really hard in the past - years to improve the flexibility of training and work patterns, but there is no doubt that there is more that we could do."Online events during Womens Week areopen to the public.For more information visithttps:friendsofgri.org womens-week or follow @FriendsofGRI on Twitter.You can donate to the Friends of GRI charity on https:www.justgiving friendsofgri

title: kevin-mckenna-richard-dawkins-got-wrong-people-downs-syndrome
story: The petition I signed last week was organised by the Downrsquos syndrome charity Donrsquot Screen Us Out in response to comments made by the scientist Richard Dawkins in a recent interview with Brendan OrsquoConnor, the Irish radio presenter. During it, Mr OrsquoConnor asks Professor Dawkinshe stands by advice he once offered to a woman who was unsure of the correct course of action in the event of being pregnant with a Downrsquos syndrome baby. The professor had told her: ldquoAbort it and try again. It would be immoral to bring it into the worldyou have a choice.Mr OrsquoConnor declares his interest in this debate from the outset. He has a daughter with Downrsquos syndrome but he maintains a high level of professional detachment throughout the interview and conducts it in a spirit of polite inquiry. What follows from Professor Dawkins is perhaps the bleakest evaluation of humanity yoursquore likely to hear in a modern setting. What adds to the chill factor, I think, is that it also prescribes an inevitable direction of travel when the state presumes to legislate on matters surrounding end-of-le care.: English Tory triumph means that independence is our last refuge, by Kevin McKennaThe professor partially retreats from his original opinion by withdrawing the term lsquoimmoralrsquo. He suggests rather that it would be ldquowise and sensible in such circumstances to opt for an abortion. His justication for this is his assertion that ldquothe amount of suffering in the world probably does not go down ndash probably goes up ndash compared to having another child who doesnrsquot have Downrsquos syndrome. Professor Dawkins, a biologist who appeals to scientic fact during his regular trolling of people who profess religious faith, admits his view about what constitutes lsquosufferingrsquo is evidence-free. ldquoIt seems to me to be plausible I have no direct evidence, he tells the interviewer when pressed.Wersquoll leave aside the issue of how much an affluent white man residing in a rich country can ever fully grasp the concept of human suffering and its effects. These happy accidents of birth and the advantages they have bestowed on Mr Dawkins means he will always be inoculated from the suffering of multitudes of other humans less favoured. As a gted biologist the professor has used his advantages well in advancing our understanding of ourselves and the world we inhabit. Inexplicably though, the knowledge he has gathered about the beautul ersity of creation seems not to have increased his compassion for it, but soiled it. What he is professing amounts to eugenics: the belief that only the fittest or best-equipped among us deserve to experience quality in our lives.Here, I must declare my own interest in this issue: I have a niece with Downrsquos syndrome. Itrsquos impossible to convey in a column such as this how much hurt she would feel, knowing that another human being harboured thoughts such as these how reduced how unloved how devalued. Ciara is a young woman now and, having known only the love of a large extended family, is embarking on a journey into adulthood and a future that holds the promise of good things.She has already represented her country in ious sports and, thanks to the skills, dedication and compassion of her primary school teachersshe is living a full le. She is also contributing to the happiness of others, this being a basic requirement for peaceful co-existence on earth. Professor Dawkins in his cruel, arrogant ignorance believes she and millions of others with Downrsquos syndrome are incapable of such. And lacking any evidence he chooses to see only that which he regards as other and abnormal and that these must be feared ndash and thus destroyed. It is the philosophy of Salem.Richard DawkinsYou hesitate to sign an entreaty that might adversely affect anotherrsquos ability to earn their keep. The Donrsquot Screen Us Out petition though, leaves room for Professor Dawkins to reconsider his views and their consequences for humanitythey ever entered the mainstream. It says this: ldquoPenguin Random House publishes Richard Dawkinsrsquo books. As a company, they make it clear that they ldquocelebrate and actively promote ersity and inclusion in all its forms, including and not limited to the nine protected characteristics cited in The Equality Act  including ldquodisability. They go on to say that ldquoIt is not acceptable to make dismissive or hostile remarks about a person on any basis or to make assumptions about someonersquos lestyle, interests or abilities.You may be tempted to dismiss criticism of the professor on the basis that, as a high-profile atheist they are consistent with a view that there is no ultimate force for good and that we must simply let the dice roll as they please. lsquoMoralityrsquo being merely existential, this is a grand space to inhabit in which you can set your own boundaries on what you consider to be lsquogoodrsquo. It conveniently frees us from any moral obligation to make the world lsquobetterrsquo.:Downs children like my beautul niece Ciara are a gt ndash not a burdenYet, itrsquos not on the basis of uncertain and precarious religious faith that we must disdain Professor Dawkinsrsquo barren evaluation of humanity. None of us was born complete. We will never be the finished article. At some point in our lives we will require to be fixed and restored. On these occasions the healing can only be provided by others and rests on their willingness to give something of themselves while asking nothing in .For many, the brokenness is long-lasting or permanent and may never be healed. This will call for an extraordinary measure of unconditional devotion that resists the urge to calculate cost or predict benefits. Itrsquos perhaps the most perfect love of all, but itrsquos one which we all have the capacity to offer. Richard Dawkins possesses it too and Irsquom sad that he under-estimates his own ability to reach it.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: herald-view-tome-cabinet-get-work-behalf-us
story: But there is an equal obligation for the public to acknowledge any newly-elected governmentrsquos mandate, to wish it the best and give it a chance. Opposition, scrutiny and challenge should play a part in that, but in a constructive spirit.If the Governmentrsquos charge is to improve the nationrsquos position and prospects, opposition politicians, the press and the electorate ought to support measures toward that end, rather than reflexively objecting. But they need not be shy of advancing ideas for improvement or refinement of policy.This has never been more important. During the pandemic, much of the knee-jerk partisan position-taking of which governments and opposition parties are frequently guilty was set aside, as politicians grasped the urgent realities of the crisis.Despite the numerous criticisms that could be, and were, made of governmentsrsquo actions or other partiesrsquo positions, a remarkable degree of consensus was achieved, both within parliaments, and among the parliaments of the UK. Such an approach, a clear necessity in the emergency, ought also to be the aim in constructing recovery from it.Whatever the previous errors and mis-steps, Scotland and the UK as a whole are emerging strongly, with a very successful vaccine programme. Almost certainly as a result of that, the UK currently has by far the lowest number of cases of any European country. Vigilance against new iants and maintaining a cautious, common-sense approach remain important, but that position indicates that governments can turn to long-term policy in other areas, many of them seriously damaged during the pandemic and vital to recovery.Health and social care ndash which, after the misjudgments around care homes, it is obvious should be tackled together ndash remain a top priority as weto routine treatment for other diseases, face-to-face GPsrsquo surgeries, and the huge backlog that has inevitably been created. Urgently catching up with patients with other conditions will require funding, of course, but that cannot be the whole answer, or costs will simply spiral ever upwards. Imaginative, pragmatic and dogma-free approaches will be required.Education, badly interrupted for so many, despite schoolsrsquo and universitiesrsquo best efforts, will be another area crucial to recovery. A modern economy relies on an educated workforce, and industry on skills and training. The Governmentrsquos policies to this point have, at the very least, failed to meet its own expectations. Rather than criticisms being greeted with instinctive denials and affront, now is the time to rethink and work to restore Scotlandrsquos previously admirable reputation for equitable, high-quality education provision.One piece of good news is that the UK economy has proven more robust than expected, but Scotlandrsquos spending still outstrips its counterparts where in the UK, and signicant growth and understanding of businessrsquos needs is essential. Transport connectivity will play a huge role in that: devolved rail must match and work with changes being introduced where, the dreadful ferriesrsquo fiasco must be sorted, and the state of the roads urgently addressed.Some of this is the work of local government, which should have the proper resources to tackle potholes, housing, welfare and other fundamental services and amenities. That should involve more freedom from Holyrood, but with that comes responsibility. Taxpayers, at every level, fund such nuts-and-bolts issues, and have a right to expect accountability, decent services, value for money, and aon investment. It is our money, not the Governmentrsquos, and must be more effectively deployed.We should approach these issues forcefully, and positively. Whatever your own politics, this Government has strong popular support, an experienced team, and a capable First Minister. It should be familiar with the mechanisms for delivering on these priorities and be encouraged, both by active support and constructive challenge, to get to work on them.

title: netherton-archaeologists-find-mysterious-ancient-iron-dagger-excevations
story: But now archaeologists who excavated thelsquolost village of Nethertonsay its inhabitants may have put their trust in an ancient talisman to protect them from harm - after making a startling and mysterious find in the remains of one of the settlementrsquos ruined buildings.The village of Nethertonwas uncovered in North Lanarkshire during work to upgrade theM, M and M Improvements.Thought to have been settled sometime in the thcentury ndash placing it in the medievalperiod -the village was inhabited untilthe s when it was demolishedby the Dukes of Hamilton as they transformed their estate into well-ordered and symmetricalparkland with wide avenues and enclosures.What remained of the village was then destroyed with the construction of the motorway ndash save for the remains of four housesright on the hard shoulder.The remains of four homes were found next tothe motorwayAn excavation of these ruins was carried outin  by experts from GUARD Archaeology, and the final report has now revealed a mysterious find totally out of place with the rest of the site.Underneath one of the buildings, inamongst the foundations, was a dagger which dates back ,years to the Iron Age.The blade, buried initssheathe and likely still useable when it was deposited, was found alongside other items-awhetstone of fine-grained sandstone, a spindle whorl made of cannel coal, a possible gaming piece made from green glaze pottery, and two seventeenth century coins-whichdate to the time thehouse was built.:Most detailed maps of Culloden ever created mark anniversaryIt is thought the weapon was intentionally laid downas a good luck charm in the belief its ancient magic would keep the inhabitants safe from harm.ldquoMineralisedorganic material on its blade suggests it was sheathed when buried, and that it was probably intact and still useable at that time,rsquo said Gemma Cruickshanks of National Museums Scotland, whoanalysedthe metalwork. ldquoThe form of this dagger is indistinguishable from Iron Age examples, indicating this simple dagger form had a very long history.An artists impressiom of how the village may have lookedThe practice of depositing special objects in medieval and post-medieval buildings is well documented and was a ritual performed to protect the building and its inhabitants.In this case, the archaeologists believethe daggerrsquosldquopotential antiquity as a prehistoric objectperhaps lent it a quality of lsquootherness.rsquoReuse of prehistoric objects as depositions in medieval settings has been recorded in excavations ofchurches in England, and flint arrowheads were traditionally identied as lsquoelf-boltsrsquo and longrecognisedfor their malevolent magical properties.:From a big pile of stones to an award-winning Scots monument - Clachtoll Broch is rescue project of the yearldquoThe special or talismanic qualities of this dagger as a protective object may have enhanced the ritual act to protect the household from worldly and magical harm, said Natasha Ferguson, another of the reportrsquos co-authors.ldquoThe deposition of these objects under the foundation level of one of the houses may have been intended to affirm this space as a place of safety for them and generations to come.

title: uk-travel-germany-bar-britons-amid-covid-variant-spread
story: From midnight on Sunday, May , people travelling to Germany from Great Britain and Northern Ireland may only enter the countrythey are German citizens or residents.Spouses and children under  of a German citizen or resident can also enter, as long as they aretravelling together as a household.:Why blaming vaccine hesitancy for outbreaks lets politicians off the hookExceptions include urgent humanitarian reasons, such as an immediate family bereavement, however, UK travellers must quarantine for two weeks on arrival, eventhey test negative for the virus.People who are only transferring from one flight to another will still be allowed in as long asthey remain in the airport transit area.In Germany, authorities have started easingcoronavirus restrictions.While Brits are banned from travelling there, the locals are now allowed to meet up with friends and family at outdoor venues.Germany had already ltedcurfews and quarantine rules on people who were fully vaccinated or had recovered from the virus, as well as the obligation to provide a negative test result to access shops and other services.The move comes after Spain lted travel restrictions on British visitors, with the countryrsquos prime minister Pedro Sanchez saying Spain will be ldquodelighted, extremely delighted to receive British tourists again.:Covid vaccine passport scheme announced for ScotlandSpain is lting its restrictions on travellers from the United Kingdom beginning on Monday.Germany and Spain are both on the Governmentrsquos amber list, meaning travellers must quarantine at home for  days and take a pre-departure test and two post-arrival tests.

title: two-doses-pfizer-coronavirus-vaccine-88-percent-effective-indian-variant-finds-study
story: Both the Pfizer and AstraZeneca jabs were found to be almost as effective against symptomatic disease from the B. strain as they are against the Kent iant after the second dose.Health Secretary Matt Hancock described the outcome as ldquogroundbreaking, while PHE said it expects to see even higher levels of effectiveness against hospital admission and death.The study, which took place between April  and May , found that the Pfizer vaccine was % effective against symptomatic disease from the Indian iant two weeks after the second dose, compared with % effectiveness against the Kent strain.Meanwhile, the AstraZeneca jab was % effective, compared with % against the Kent iant over the same period.:Coronavirus Scotland:  new Covid cases in  hours and no new deathsBoth vaccines were % effective against symptomatic disease from the Indian iant three weeks after the first dose, compared with about % against the Kent strain.Some , genome-sequenced cases were included in the analysis, but only , were of the Indian iant.The study included data for all age groups from April  to cover the period since the strain emerged.New data from PHE shows there have been at least , cases of the Indian iant recorded in England from February  this year to May .Of those,  cases resulted in a visit to a hospital emergency department,  required an overnight hospital admission and six resulted in a death.The most common strain in England, according to the data, is the Kent iant, with , cases recorded since the same date.Some , people have died with the iant, while , cases resulted in an overnight hospital admission and , required a visit to a hospital emergency department.Dr Jamie Lopez Bernal, consultant medical epidemiologist at PHE and the studyrsquos lead author, said there was more confidence in the data from the first vaccine dose compared with that from the second.:Why blaming vaccine hesitancy for outbreaks lets politicians off the hookHe said: ldquoThere are bigger numbers that have been vaccinated with one dose. So I think we classy that as moderate certainty around the first dose, but low levels of confidence around the second dose.PHE said the dference in the effectiveness between the vaccines may be due to the AstraZeneca second dose being rolled out later than the Pfizer vaccine.Data also shows it takes longer for the AstraZeneca jab to reach maximum effectiveness.There are insufficient cases and follow-up periods to estimate vaccine effectiveness against severe outcomes from the Indian iant but this will be evaluated over the coming weeks, PHE added.Asked about how the data could affect the easing of restrictions from June , Prof Hopkins said it was ldquotoo early to say.She said: ldquoOne week post the last restriction lting, we will be monitoring it very carefully.Mr Hancock said: ldquoThis new evidence is groundbreaking and proves just how valuable our Covid- vaccination programme is in protecting the people we love.ldquoWe can now be confident that over  million people ndash more than one in three ndash have signicant protection against this new iant, and that number is growing by the hundreds of thousands every single day as more and more people get that vital second dose.Dr Mary Ramsay, head of immunisation at PHE, added: ldquoThis study provides reassurance that two doses of either vaccine offer high levels of protection against symptomatic disease from the B. iant.ldquoWe expect the vaccines to be even more effective at preventing hospitalisation and death, so it is vital to get both doses to gain maximum protection against all existing and emerging iants.

title: xponorth-2021-outlander-producer-among-stellar-guests
story: XpoNorth  will see a rich  of speakers from creative, digital and heritage sectors, like Outlanderrsquos producer, Michael Wilson, a TV historian, as well as an international rugby star turned
